column2: də NANG
column3: NAHNG; Vietnamese: Đà Nẵng
column4: [ɗâː nǎˀŋ] (listen)) is a class-1 municipality and the fifth-largest city in Vietnam by population. It lies on the coast of the South China Sea at the mouth of the Han River
column5: and is one of Vietnam's most important port cities. As one of the country's five direct-controlled municipalities
column6: it falls under the administration of the central government.

column1: Da Nang is the commercial and educational centre of Central Vietnam and is the largest city in the region. It has a well-sheltered
column2: easily accessible port
column3: and its location on National Route 1A and the North–South Railway makes it a transport hub. It is within 100 km (62 mi) of several UNESCO World Heritage Sites
column4: including the Imperial City of Hue
column5: the Old Town of Hoi An
column6: and the My Son ruins. The city was known as Cửa Hàn during early Đại Việt settlement
column7: and as Tourane (or Turon) during French colonial rule. Before 1997
column8: the city was part of Quang Nam-Da Nang Province.

column2: Da Nang was separated from Quảng Nam Province to become one of four centrally controlled municipalities in Vietnam. Da Nang is designated as a first class city
column3: and has a higher urbanization ratio than any of Vietnam's other provinces or centrally governed cities.

column1: Most of the names by which Da Nang has been known make reference to its position at the Hàn River estuary. The city's present name is generally agreed to be a Vietnamese adaptation of the Cham word da nak
column2: which is translated as "opening of a large river".
with similar definitions
column3: have been proposed. Inrasara (aka Phú Trạm)
column4: a researcher specializing in Champa
column5: suggests Da Nang is a variation of the Cham word daknan (lit. "the large water"); Sakaya (aka Văn Món)
column6: another Champa researcher
column7: claims a connection with the Raglai word danang
column8: meaning "river source".Another name given to Da Nang was Cửa Hàn (lit. "mouth of the Han [river]"). The name used by the French
column10: is said to derive from this name
column11: by way of a rough transliteration. Notably
column12: this name (spelled "Cua han") appears on maps of the area drafted by Alexandre de Rhodes in 1650. The name Kean (cf. Kẻ Hàn
column13: roughly "Han market") was another name purportedly used during the 17th century to refer to the land at the foot of the Hải Vân Pass.Other names referring to Da Nang include:

column1: The city's origins date back to the ancient kingdom of Champa
column2: established in 192 AD. At its peak
column3: the Chams' sphere of influence stretched from Huế to Vũng Tàu. The city of Indrapura
column4: at the site of the modern village of Dong Duong in Quảng Nam Province (about 50 km (31 mi) from Da Nang)
column5: was the capital of Champa from about 875 to about 1000 AD. Also in the region of Da Nang were the ancient Cham city of Singhapura ("City of the Lion")
column6: the location of which has been identified with an archeological site in the modern village of Trà Kiệu
column7: and the valley of Mỹ Sơn
column8: where a number of ruined temples and towers can still be viewed.

column1: In the latter half of the 10th century
column2: the kings of Indrapura came into conflict with the Đại Việt
column3: who were then based at Hoa Lư near modern Hanoi. In 982
column4: three ambassadors sent to Champa by emperor Lê Hoàn of the Đại Việt (founder of the Early Lê Dynasty) were detained in Indrapura. Lê Hoàn decided to go on the offensive
column5: sacking Indrapura and killing the Cham King Parameshvaravarman I. As a result of these setbacks
column6: the Cham eventually abandoned Indrapura around 1000 AD.The Đại Việt campaign against Champa continued into the late 11th century
column7: when the Cham were forced to cede their three northern provinces to the rulers of the Lý Dynasty. Soon afterward
column8: Vietnamese peasants began moving into the untilled former Cham lands
column9: turning them into rice fields and moving relentlessly southward
column11: along the narrow coastal plain. The southward expansion of Đại Việt (known as Nam Tiến) continued for several centuries
column12: culminating in the annexation of most of the Cham territories by the end of the 15th century.

column1: One of the first Europeans to visit Da Nang was Portuguese explorer António de Faria

column7: just south of Đà Nẵng. An American
column8: John White
column9: arrived at Da Nang (then called Turon) on 18 June 1819 in the brig Franklin of Salem
column11: and was advised that the country was recovering from devastating wars
column12: and that what little produce there had already been promised. Other American ships arriving shortly after were the Marmion of Boston
column13: and the Aurora and Beverly of Salem.Conditions were such due to the wars that they were unable to conduct trade
column14: and the subsequent missions of East India Company agent John Crawfurd in 1823 and the two missions of Andrew Jackson's agent
column16: in 1833 and 1836 were unable to secure trade agreements due to the exceptionally poor quality of the port. Following the edict of Emperor Minh Mạng in 1835
column17: prohibiting European vessels from making landfall or pursuing trade except at Hàn Port

column2: French vessels dispatched by Admiral Cécille bombarded Đà Nẵng

column1: The French overpowered the Vietnamese stationed in Da Nang
column2: swiftly occupying the city and Tiên Sa peninsula (present-day Sơn Trà peninsula). The occupying forces were quickly placed under siege by the Vietnamese army under the command of Nguyễn Tri Phương
column3: and were eventually forced to retreat in March 1860. The French were able to invade the southern stronghold of Saigon and
column4: in June 1862
column5: several provinces of southern Vietnam were ceded to the French as Cochinchina with the signing of the Treaty of Saigon.

column1: Through two more decades of conflict

column2: what is now the Da Nang International Airport was a major air base used by the South Vietnamese and United States Air Forces.

column1: The base became one of the world's busiest aircraft hubs during the war
column2: reaching an average of 2
column3: 595 aircraft traffic operations daily
column4: more than any other airport and airbase in the world at that time. The final U.S. ground combat operations in Vietnam ceased on 13 August 1972
column5: when a residual force of the 196th Light Infantry Brigade stood down in Đà Nẵng. B Battery 3rd Battalion
column6: 82nd Field Artillery Regiment fired the final U.S. artillery round and the 3rd Battalion
column7: 21st Infantry Regiment finished their final patrols. This residual force was known as "Operation Gimlet".

column1: After the US withdrawal from the conflict

column1: Da Nang is the largest city in central Vietnam and one of the country's most important ports. The city is surrounded by mountains to the west
column2: and the South China Sea to the east. Da Nang borders Thừa Thiên-Huế Province across the Hải Vân Pass to the north
column3: along with the Quảng Nam Province to the south and west. It is 764 km (475 mi) south of Hanoi
column4: and 964 km (599 mi) north of Ho Chi Minh City. The city has a total land area of 1
column6: of which 241.51 km2 (93.25 sq mi) are urban districts and 1
column7: 041.91 km2 (402.28 sq mi) are rural districts.

column2: Da Nang is at the edge of a Paleozoic fold belt known as the Truong Son Orogenic Zone
column3: whose main deformation occurred during the early Carboniferous period. Da Nang's topography is dominated by the steep Annamite mountain range to the north and north-west
column4: which features peaks ranging from 700 to 1
column5: 500 metres (2
column7: 900 ft) in height
column8: and low-lying coastal plains with some salting to the south and east
column9: with several white sand beaches along the coast.

column1: Da Nang has a tropical monsoon climate with two seasons: a typhoon and wet season from September to December and a dry season from January to August. Temperatures have an annual average of around 26 °C (79 °F). Cold waves can occasionally occur although they are of short duration. Temperatures are highest between June and August with mean temperatures of 28 to 30 °C (82 to 86 °F))
column2: and lowest between December and February (mean temperature of 18 to 23 °C (64 to 73 °F)). In Ba Na Hills
column3: the temperatures are lower with an annual average of 20 °C (68 °F). The annual average for humidity is 81%
column4: with highs between October and January (reaching 84–86%) and lows between June and August (reaching 75–77%).On average
column5: Da Nang receives 2
column6: 153 mm (84.8 in) of rainfall. Rainfall is typically highest between September and November (ranging from 550 to 1
column7: 000 mm (22 to 39 in)) and lowest between February and April (ranging from 23 to 40 mm (0.91 to 1.57 in)). Da Nang receives an average of 2156 hours of sunlight annually
column8: with highs between 234 and 277 hours per month in May and June and lows between 69 and 165 hours per month in November and December.

column1: Da Nang is susceptible to damage from typhoons that cross into the South China Sea. In 2006
column2: the landfall of Typhoon Xangsane near the city of Hue caused 26 deaths in Da Nang
column3: damaging and destroying homes
column4: downing trees and power lines and flooding major streets.Authorities in Da Nang estimated the damage caused by Xangsane at around US$200 million
column5: with more than 5
column6: 000 houses washed away
column8: 000 homes damaged and 19 boats sunk. Three years later
column9: Typhoon Ketsana made its landfall about 37 miles (60 km) south of Da Nang
column10: again causing widespread flooding. Ketsana left eight people dead and 96 injured in Da Nang
column11: and caused an estimated VND 495 billion (US$25 million) in damage.Shortly after the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake
column13: the People's Committee of Da Nang approved the installation of 10 early tsunami warning stations throughout the city
column14: the first of their kind in Vietnam. Officials expected the stations would provide at least thirty minutes of warning in case of a tsunami. According to Le Huy Minh
column15: Director of the Earthquake and Tsunami Warning Centre at the Vietnam Institute of Geophysics
column16: a powerful earthquake (≥8 MW) in the waters north of the Philippines could pose a significant danger to the Vietnamese coastline
column17: particularly the area around Da Nang.

column1: Da Nang is the sixth most populated city in Vietnam
column2: with an area of 1
column3: 255.53 km2 (484.76 sq mi) and a population of 1
column5: 100 as the latest update in 2017. Women make up 50.7% of Da Nang's population.

column1: Population growthDa Nang's population has been growing at rates of between 2.5% and 3% during most of the years between 2005 and 2011
column2: significantly exceeding the national average of 1% to 1.2%. The growth rate briefly rose to 3.6% in 2010 before returning to its long-term trend with 2.68% in 2011. This is the third fastest growth rate in the country after the two southern manufacturing centers Bình Dương Province (4.41%) and Đồng Nai Province (3.5%).Đà Nẵng's population is estimated to reach one million inhabitants by 2014.

column1: Migration has been the dominant factor in the city's population growth at least since 2009
column2: contributing 1.6% to 2.7% (2010) between 2009 and 2011. Out-migration has been relatively high in 2011 at 0.79% compared to 0.34% and 0.55% in previous years
column3: while the in-migration rate has been exceeding 2% since 2009 and was at 2.28% in 2011.Đà Nẵng's natural population growth is only slightly higher than the national average. Its crude birth rate was recorded at 18 live births per 1000 persons. The crude death rate was measured at 6.7 per 1000 persons in 2011. Life expectancy at birth was estimated at 77.4 years for women and 72.4 years for men
column4: or 74.8 years overall in the 2009 population census. The infant mortality rate was measured at 9.9 infant deaths per 1000 live births
column5: less than two points above the nation's average for urban areas.

column1: UrbanizationThe city has the highest urbanization ratio among provinces and municipalities in Vietnam
column2: containing only 11 rural communes
column3: the fewest of any province-level unit in Vietnam. As of 2009
column4: 86.9% of Đà Nẵng's population lived in urban areas; average annual urban population growth was 3.5%.

column1: The leading organ of the Communist Party in Da Nang City is the Executive Committee of the Communist Party. The current Secretary is Truong Quang Nghia.
The legislative branch of the city is the People's Council of Da Nang City. The current Chairman is Nguyen Nho Trung.
The executive branch of the city is the People's Committee of Da Nang City. The current Chairman is Huynh Duc Tho.

column1: Mỹ Sơn is an archaeological site dating back more than a thousand years
column2: in Quang Nam. Located in a remote forested valley some 70 km west of Da Nang
column3: this former capital and religious center of the Champa kingdom once contained in excess of 70 style temples and stupas. Although badly damaged by bombing raids in the 1960s
column4: the site still has more than 20 structures and was declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1999. Many statues
column5: sculptures and reliefs recovered from Mỹ Sơn are kept in the Museum of Cham Sculpture
column6: near the Hàn River in the heart of Da Nang. Dating from the fourth to the 14th centuries
column7: the sensual artwork on these works depicts daily activities as well as Hindu and Buddhist religious themes.

column1: The Marble Mountains are rocky limestone outcrops jutting out of the beach just south of Da Nang. Paths lead to the top of the forested cliffs
column2: providing views of Non Nuoc Beach and the South China Sea. The caves in the cliffs were originally inhabited by the Cham people. Later
column3: the Nguyen Dynasty built numerous pagodas among the caves. The Marble Mountains are home to various artisans producing sculpture and artwork at its base at Non Nuoc Village.

column6: and entertainment facilities. Ba Na Hills is a mountain resort with a 5 km-long cable car system which carries guests up to Ba Na's peak at 1487m above sea level. Son Tra Mountain

column1: Da Nang is a major station along the North–South Railway
